prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In Physica A 564 (2021) 125498, L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, and colleagues present a multi-layer network model. In this model, each social layer includes nodes representing people and weighted connections representing social contact that could result in infection based on a probability value between 0 and 1. The first layer focuses on home interactions and consists of groups of varying sizes that are fully connected internally. These groups do not have external connections, reflecting disconnected components representing individual families. The distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2009, ranging from 1 to 14 members, is considered to determine the size of each group, with probabilities assigned to families with sizes from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country engages in work or economic activities, which involve interacting with others and are crucial for social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model this, we propose a generic layer that connects individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Argentina's total population. Given the diversity of job types and companies, establishing a connection rule that accurately mirrors the real world is complex. In our approach, we consider random groups of sizes ranging from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected, similar to the "home" layer illustrated in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. The transmission of the virus within these groups depends on edge weights, a topic we delve into further in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation plays a vital role in cities, serving as a hotspot for potential virus spread due to high occupancy and constant movement. Our third layer represents these public transport systems, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the use of public transport varies depending on city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other areas, averaging around 1.2 hours of use per day. To model this layer, we randomly select 50% of the population to participate, forming groups of 10 to 40 individuals that are fully connected.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: The multi-layer network proposed in the study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) depicts different social layers with nodes representing people and weighted connections symbolizing social contact that could lead to infection. The first layer represents home interactions and consists of groups with varied sizes based on the Argentinian family size distribution for 2010. Each group is fully connected internally but has no external connections, reflecting disconnected family units. The distribution considers family sizes from 1 to 10, ensuring each family has at least one adult. The structure of this layer for a population of 100 is shown in Figure 2(a). Another significant factor in social relations, especially during an epidemic, is work. To represent work interactions, a generic layer connects people aged 18 to 59 years, which accounts for 60% of the total population in Argentina. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into how the transmission of a virus within a fully connected group of nodes depends primarily on the edge weights. Public transportation systems are crucial in many cities but can be highly congested, making them potentially significant in the spread of an epidemic due to the constant movement of vehicles. Our proposed third layer focuses on these public transports, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of public transport users varies based on city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], typically spending an average of 1.2 hours a day on public transport. We consider an average participation rate of 50% from the total population and randomly create groups ranging in size from 10 to 40, with fully connected nodes within each group. This diversity in group sizes reflects the various public transport scenarios found in different cities in Argentina. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/argentinos-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 25.
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study conducted by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers examined the impact of various interventions on the overall course of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation began with an initial social network structure and infection probabilities. The virus was introduced at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread over daily iterations for up to 300 days. The study assumed an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 25 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context: .The activities remaining on these layers are services that cannot be halted, such as essential services, activities that continue with increased precautionary measures while disregarding the quarantine. In this scenario, we examine how the β parameter affects the overall shape of the epidemic. Figure 4(a) displays results for four different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths, spanning up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to a faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. Conversely, the epidemic concludes more quickly due to natural immunity in recovered individuals. When compared to real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, using β = 0.3 provides a closer fit to the actual scenario where mask-wearing and precautionary measures are common. The model aligns well with the data within standard deviation, although variations in diagnosed cases and deaths may be attributed to increased testing and fluctuating isolation levels. The average daily death toll predicted by the model is higher than the official numbers, likely due to underdetection rates and limited testing capacity. Continued monitoring and analysis are necessary to further understand the dynamics of the epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. examined the impact of various interventions on the course of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The research began by modeling a social network with its original structure and infection probabilities. The initial spread of the virus started at a node with a degree closest to the network average, with daily iterations lasting up to 300 days. In their analysis, the researchers considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the beginning, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1. This represented a form of natural social distancing, with reduced physical contact and increased hygiene practices. The study found that this starting value of β provided results that closely matched the Colombia pandemic data.

After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was introduced to simulate the measures implemented by most Colombian states on March 24. This quarantine involved removing certain social layers (such as religious activities and schools) and reducing contacts in transportation and workplaces to 30% of their initial levels (β = 0.09). Activities that continued at full capacity represented essential services or those taking extra precautions. The researchers analyzed how varying the β parameter affected the epidemic curve, with the results illustrated in Fig. 4. Higher β values led to quicker disease spread and higher numbers of cases and deaths, but also resulted in faster herd immunity development.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Colombian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The recent increase in diagnosed cases in Colombia over the last ten days may be attributed to the rise in testing or the decreasing isolation levels in the country, which have been consistently below 50% for most days of the past month. We assumed a fixed isolation level similar to what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Colombia, but data indicates that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than what is reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). The average daily death toll predicted by the models is higher than the official numbers, likely due to underdetection rates and limited testing. Analysis of the number of deaths in Colombia from January 1 to April 30 shows a clear increasing pattern after the first confirmed case of COVID-19 on February 26, suggesting that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported. 

Looking ahead, after the initial epidemic phase, we are considering four potential courses of action following 90 days (May 26): a) Maintaining current isolation levels without further action; b) Ending isolation and returning to normal activities with initial network layers and weights; c) Resuming only work activities with restored initial layer probabilities; or d) Increasing isolation by suspending all remaining activities related to work and transport.

author: enrique
pre_context: Scabini, Ribas, and M.B. conducted the study. Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 (a) Analysis of different β values and their impacts on the shape of new cases and deaths. (b) Comparison between the proposed model best Fig. 4. fit (
post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 17) to 4 different data sources of the Argentinian COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42]. The dashed lines in the graph represent the standard deviation, with the curve showing the average over a 5-day period and the solid lines indicating the actual raw data. The higher average number of deaths predicted by the model may be due to underdetection. In order to analyze the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Argentina, we compared official death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same time period (January 1 to April 30). The discrepancy in total deaths between these records and those reported by the WHO and the Argentinian government suggests a significant underdetection of COVID-19 cases. By implementing a strict lockdown after 90 days, we see a significant decrease in infection and death counts compared to other scenarios. The recovery time is also much faster, with daily new cases peaking around day 93 and daily new deaths increasing until day 106. By day 300, the total diagnosed cases and deaths are estimated to be 552,855 and 87,059 respectively. This analysis also allows us to estimate the number of hospital beds needed for both severe and critical cases. Additionally, we compare the cumulative growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases with those of recovered cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, researchers examined three possible scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining the current level of isolation, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing for the virus is limited due to a low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus. As a result, only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days since the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented, including the suspension of schools and religious activities, with work and transportation operating at only 30% capacity. After 90 days, various options were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation completely, or only returning work activities. The analysis indicated that maintaining current isolation levels could lead to prolonged transmission, with an estimated peak around June 5 resulting in an average of 11,000 new daily cases and 1900 daily deaths. It is projected to have 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity around June 11, but with proper management of resources, the situation could potentially remain under control. However, this optimistic scenario relies on maintaining social isolation levels above 50%, which have been challenging to achieve in Argentina. Social isolation levels in Argentina have been consistently low.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days. These scenarios include maintaining current isolation levels, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation. The study notes that testing is limited by the low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus. Only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases remain undiagnosed and continue to interact within the network. The study assumes that mild cases are aware of their symptoms and self-isolate at home, while severe and critical cases are hospitalized and isolated from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and
post_context: , and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. Hospitals could potentially reach full capacity by June 11 in this situation. Yet, if new ICU beds are quickly put into use and patients are managed effectively, the situation may still be manageable. However, this optimistic outlook is based on our definition of "keeping isolation" as having social isolation rates above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine. Currently, social isolation levels in Argentina remain around 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers examined the impact of different scenarios on the total number of infected and recovered cases, as well as hospital bed utilization after 90 days. Three possible scenarios were considered: maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Due to limitations in testing availability and speed, only hospitalization cases and a portion of mild cases were diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases were not identified and continued to interact within the network. In terms of isolating infected individuals, optimistic assumptions were made that mild cases would self-isolate at home if symptomatic, while severe and critical cases would be hospitalized and removed from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of
post_context: and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. By June 11, hospitals may reach their maximum capacity in this situation. Yet, by efficiently adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation can still be managed. However, this optimistic outlook relies on the assumption that the definition of "keep isolation" includes maintaining social isolation levels above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine [43]. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels remain at a consistent 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers examined three possible scenarios for managing the COVID-19 pandemic after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining the current isolation measures, lifting isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing limitations were noted, with only hospitalization cases and a portion of mild cases being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases were assumed to go undetected and continue to circulate in the community. The study also made assumptions about the behavior of those infected, with mild cases isolating themselves at home and severe cases being hospitalized and isolated.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of
post_context: (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.Hospitals could reach full capacity by June 11 in this situation. Yet, if new ICU beds are added and patient logistics are managed effectively, the situation may remain manageable. However, this optimistic outlook is based on the assumption that social isolation rates remain above 50%, as seen at the start of the Colombian quarantine. Colombia's social isolation levels have been consistently around 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (Physica A 564, 2021, 125498), different scenarios were considered after 90 days of the COVID-19 pandemic. These scenarios include maintaining current isolation levels, ending isolation, or increasing isolation measures such as stopping work and public transportation. Testing limitations due to low test availability or the rapid spread of the virus were also acknowledged. The study assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, with asymptomatic cases not being identified. The analysis included optimistic assumptions such as mild cases being aware of their symptoms and isolating at home, while severe and critical cases are hospitalized and fully isolated from the community.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and
post_context: until the end of the year.In this situation, hospitals may reach maximum capacity by around June 11. However, if new ICU beds are added efficiently and patients are managed well logistically, the situation can still be controlled. This is a optimistic assumption, as we define "maintaining isolation" as social isolation levels above 50%, as observed at the start of the Argentine quarantine [43]. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels remain at around 12%.
